text:
In Gaza, even language is weaponized. Israeli soldiers leave behind graffiti that degrades, mocks, and haunts. Donya Abu Sitta reflects on how words, like bombs, can wound and occupy the ruins of homes and minds.
www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

She once studied poetry under Refaat Alareer. Her mother made her egg sandwiches every morning. Her home and university are now rubble. Her mother and professor were taken in the war. In Gaza, Shahad Ali writes about all that was lost, and what survives.

www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

When the classroom is a tent and the dream is survival. In Gaza, students study by flashlight, under bombs, and through grief. This powerful essay by Taqwa al-Wawi honors their defiance and asks: how do you dream when your school no longer exists?

www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

This week on Palestine Square: voices from Gaza that refuse to be silenced. From the grief and memory of a student writer, to Hebrew graffiti used as a weapon of control, to students preparing for exams in tents and ruins, these are stories of survival, dignity, and resistanceüßµ

Zohran Mamdani has never shied away from speaking out for Palestine. In a climate where most stay silent, his victory in the NYC mayoral primary marks a major shift. His campaign proves that standing for Palestinian rights can be a winning stance.

www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

Today we honor Professor Walid Khalidi on his 100th birthday! Scholar, teacher, and co-founder of IPS, he shaped global understanding of the Nakba and Palestinian history, and devoted his life to preserving Palestinian memory against erasure.

www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

‚ÄúPalestine and the Production of Ignorance‚Äù by Muhammad Ali Khalidi traces how US institutions are suppressing knowledge about Palestine through censorship, false narratives, and smear campaigns. A must-read on the war against truth.

www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

What does it mean to teach, write, and learn under in a time of extreme censorship?

Join us for a JPS webinar on July 22 featuring Lara Deeb, Muhannad Ayyash, Rebecca Karl, and Sherene Seikaly in conversation with Nadim Bawalsa.

Register here:
www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

Israel destroyed Gaza‚Äôs printing presses, publishing houses, and bookstores. These were homes to memory, knowledge, and cultural continuity. Ink and manuscripts turned to ash. Presses were silenced mid-sentence.

Report by Fatma Al Zahraa Sehwail:
www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

Recognition without rights is not justice. As Western governments symbolically ‚Äúrecognize‚Äù Palestine, this essay by Jwan Zreiq asks: what is being recognized, and at whose expense?

www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

Alaa went to get flour for his family. He came back wrapped in empty flour bags‚Äîshot dead by Israeli forces. In this heartbreaking essay, his sister Areej Almashharawi writes about famine, survival, and the cruelty of engineered hunger in Gaza.

üîó www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

Israel isn‚Äôt just bombing Gaza‚Äîit‚Äôs arming gangs to sow chaos, starve civilians, and sabotage aid. In this harrowing report, Mohammed al-Naami exposes how the occupation weaponizes collaborators and criminal networks to dismantle Gaza from within.

www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

An important message and appeal from Rashid Khalidi, IPS-USA President and Board Chairman. For over 60 years, IPS has been the leading institution for independent Palestinian research and publishing. Our essential work needs your support.

palestine-studies.networkforgood.com/projects/254...

What does motherhood mean when hospitals are bombed and schoolbags become grave markers? Mohammed Abu Muheisen documents the unbearable weight carried by Gaza‚Äôs mothers in a war with no end.

üîó www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

Israel has destroyed, bombed, and burned nearly every hospital in Gaza. Mass graves have been found inside medical complexes. Patients, staff, and children were executed or buried alive. Mohammad al-Naami reports from the ground.

www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

Israeli forces forced Palestinian detainees to strip, kneel on freezing floors, branded them, starved them, and unleashed dogs on them. Nurse Lana Abugharbieh heard it all firsthand‚Äîand treated their broken bodies in Gaza. Read her testimony:

üîó www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

9/ Read the full policy paper on how mass disability is being used as a tool of genocide in Gaza:
üëâ www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

8/ Majadli argues that this is not a failure of international law but of enforcement. The destruction of Gaza‚Äôs health system is not just a war crime‚Äîit‚Äôs a core tactic in a campaign of elimination.

7/ Amputation is not only physical‚Äîit is political. By maiming thousands and destroying the means of healing, Israel ensures Gaza‚Äôs population is left unable to rebuild, resist, or even survive. This is national dismemberment.

6/ Now, even basic rehabilitation is impossible. There are no prosthetics, no physical therapy, no functioning inpatient rehab. Wheelchairs and crutches are in short supply. Most rehab workers are dead or displaced.

5/ This collapse didn‚Äôt begin in 2023. Israel‚Äôs blockade and control over Gaza‚Äôs medical system has long denied Palestinians access to care, equipment, medicine, and movement‚Äîwhile maintaining total dependency.
4/ 3,000 to 4,000 amputations. Thousands more with spinal cord injuries, severe burns, and trauma. Children are disabled at an average rate of 15 per day in 2024. Most will never receive proper care.

3/ Since October 2023, Israeli forces have bombed hospitals, blocked aid, and targeted healthcare workers. Tens of thousands are injured. Thousands have lost limbs. The system meant to treat them no longer exists.
2/ What happens when a healthcare system is dismantled by design? When injuries outpace the ability to treat them? When amputation is not a consequence but a strategy? This is Gaza today.

1/ Ghada Majadli examines how Israel‚Äôs systematic targeting of Gaza‚Äôs healthcare system has led to mass injuries and amputations, turning disability into a deliberate weapon of war. This policy paper details the genocidal logic behind Gaza‚Äôs health crisis.üßµ

Israel has cut Gaza off from food, water, and medicine for over two months. With UN agencies warning of famine and mass starvation, its genocidal intent is no longer hidden‚Äîit‚Äôs policy.

Read the full article: www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt treat burn wounds while the fire is still blazing.‚Äù Nurse Lana Abugharbieh recounts her mission in Gaza, where medical care collapsed under siege and bombs. Her message is clear: without a ceasefire, there is no healing.
www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

‚ÄúDisplacement is an extra limb I carry.‚Äù In a searing letter from Gaza, Shaimaa Abulebda captures the weight of exile, the terror of eleven forced displacements, and the grief that reshapes the body and soul.
www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

‚ÄúI had to choose who deserved anesthesia and who didn‚Äôt.‚Äù Dr. Alia Kattan recounts her mission in Rafah during Israel‚Äôs invasion, where Gaza‚Äôs health care system was so gutted that survival itself had to be triaged.
www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

100 days into Israel‚Äôs assault on Jenin, 18,000 have been displaced, scattered across 86 locations with no aid plan in sight. Mohammad Sabbagh asks: Where is the Palestinian Authority? Where is the urgency to protect its people?
www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

‚ÄúWe took the tube out of his throat and waited for him to pass.‚Äù Dr. Tammy Abughnaim recounts treating children under siege in Gaza, where Israeli restrictions forced doctors to choose who gets to live ‚Äî and who doesn‚Äôt.
www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

Separated by walls but united in vision. Moayed Abu Ammouna in Gaza and Adam Rouhana in Jerusalem use photography to defy borders, preserve memory, and imagine a free Palestine ‚Äî one frame at a time.
www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

As Gaza‚Äôs infrastructure is reduced to rubble, animals are dying quietly in destroyed zoos and shelters. Hadeel Farhat exposes this often unseen dimension of Israel‚Äôs war‚Äîwhere the destruction reaches every corner of life in Gaza.

www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

Israel turned Gaza‚Äôs Al-Zahra, Al-Mughraqa, and Juhr al-Dik into wastelands. It bulldozed homes, farms, schools, and hospitals to create the so-called Netzarim Corridor ‚Äî a corridor of death. 

Mohammad al-Naami documents the devastation in this report: www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

üì£We're hiring! The Jerusalem Quarterly (JQ) is currently looking for a part-time Assistant Editor. This opportunity is remote! Deadline is May 15, 2025.

Details: www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

Last month, the Independent International Commission of Inquiry on the Occupied Palestinian Territory submitted a report detailing sexual violence by the IOF against Palestinians as well as attacks on reproductive health in Gaza. Kaitlyn Cook reports: www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...
Read the full roundtable led by @najisafadi.bsky.social and scroll through the images by Moayed Abu Ammouna and Adam Rouhana on our blog here: www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

"Israel's colonial system is intent on keeping Moayed and Adam apart ‚Äî yet they use their photography to find cracks in the wall. Their art centers the hopes, stories, and dreams of Palestinians across geographies, insisting on unity in the face of division." writes @najisafadi.bsky.social

"Adam's photography works against the settler-colonial gaze, which perceives Palestinians as a threat to be subordinated, incarcerated, and eliminated. Adam's gaze, however, turns away from Palestinian death, and toward Palestinian life." writes @najisafadi.bsky.social

Adam explains that photographs, due to their unique visual form, ‚Äúhave an innate capacity for stickiness ‚Äî consolidating into lasting cognitive formations and leaving imprints of reality on our collective consciousness.‚Äù

Adam discovered Moayed's work on Instagram during the genocide, and was moved by it. He reflects, ‚ÄúFrom the [photographs] I've seen, Moayed is channeling the impossible realities of life under genocide into pictorial form.‚Äù

@najisafadi.bsky.social writes, "Moayed's work [...] does not show us the explicit violence, the bombs, the blood, or the bodies ‚Äî instead, he offers us poetic glimpses into the liminality, the inexplicable in-betweenness of an existence that is a blur between life and death."

Moayed continues, ‚ÄúThrough my images, I try to answer questions like: What were people doing before they died? What were their hopes, stories, and dreams? Everyone who dies was doing only one thing: waiting. Waiting for any miracle to stop what is happening.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy photography is a personal projection of what I feel and experience as someone who is still alive under this genocide. It is the result of long gazes at the invisible scars and details that the media doesn't document," says Moayed.

@najisafadi.bsky.social speaks with Palestinian photographers, Moayed Abu Ammouna in Gaza & Adam Rouhana in Jerusalem on how photography, and dialogue between artists, contributes to the struggle for Palestinian liberation. Read and view their photos ‚¨áÔ∏èüßµ

In this article for the Journal of Palestine Studies, Razan Shawamreh debunks China‚Äôs claim of impartiality in its foreign policy toward Palestine and Israel since 1989, and especially during the ongoing genocide in Gaza.
doi.org/10.1080/0377...

"...the failures of his negotiations with the country‚Äôs various armed actors have contributed to his low approval rating of around 30 percent, his steadfast advocacy on behalf of the Palestinian cause, rooted in part in his own history as a guerilla fighter, has also made him a target."

"But perhaps more important is the fact that the positive coverage of Petro‚Äôs actions has hidden a political reality: he is getting absolutely hammered by the press, politicians, and even many Colombian liberals. While issues like an attempted overhaul of the health sector and..."

"For one, though the government has taken steps in holding Israel to account, there remains further to go; it is often hard to parse out exactly what has been done in a context where Petro‚Äôs policies have been announced via X (formerly Twitter), communiqu√©s, or in speeches."

"For these actions, Petro has been rightly praised, even receiving the highest honor, the Grand Collar, from the State of Palestine. Highlighting Petro‚Äôs leadership on this issue, however, misses key parts of the wider political picture."
"Then, in early June, in what has until today been his most significant move, Petro called for banning Colombian coal exports to Israel; he signed a decree formalizing the ban in mid-August."

"After the Flour Massacre of February 29, 2024, in which Israel killed 118 Palestinians waiting for food aid and wounded 760 more, Petro announced that Colombia would stop buying Israeli arms. Two months later, on May 1, he announced the complete severance of diplomatic relations with Israel."

For JPS, Gabriel Levine-Drizin situates Palestinian solidarity among Colombian social movements, trade unions, & leftist President Gustavo Petro in their shared understanding of Colombia‚Äôs own internal conflict, one in which Israel has played a key role.
doi.org/10.1080/0377...

‚ÄúHe displayed 20 images of destroyed houses in Gaza as real estate ads, similar to the way brokers advertise houses for rent or sale...details of the destroyed houses in Gaza: a description of the house, its location, its proximity to the sea, the # of rooms, and the # of people who lived in it.‚Äù

‚ÄúBatniji, who lost a significant number of his family members and early works in Gaza, was forcibly displaced from Gaza in 2006. After the Israeli aggression on the Gaza Strip in 2008‚Äì9, Batniji brought the issue of house destruction closer to Western eyes,‚Äù Anani writes.

‚ÄúAs the art world parades its supposed commitment to diversity by adopting themes of decolonization and making space for voices from the Global South, it ignores that Palestinian artists are being massacred, and that their cultural institutions are being obliterated.‚Äù
doi.org/10.1080/0377...

In this essay for the Journal of Palestine Studies, Rana Anani documents how Western art institutions, despite touting themes of decolonization and post-colonialism have distanced themselves from the Palestinian decolonial struggle and marginalized and excluded Palestinian artists.

HRW released a 179-page report, titled ‚ÄúExtermination and Acts of Genocide: Israel Deliberately Depriving Palestinians of Water in Gaza.‚Äù  HRW also interviewed 31 doctors and healthcare workers who described patients of all ages who have been killed from dehydration, malnutrition, and disease.

Agnes Callamard, Amnesty's secretary-general, presented the report ‚ÄúYou Feel Like You Are Subhuman‚Äù on Thursday, Dec. 5, stating Amnesty's conclusion was unequivocal ‚Äî ‚Äúthe state of Israel has committed and is continuing to commit genocide against Palestinians in the Gaza Strip.‚Äù

In December of 2024, @amnesty.org and @hrw.org issued groundbreaking reports declaring Israel was committing acts of genocide in Gaza. Months later, their findings remain critical. ‚¨áÔ∏è
www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

Dr. Abdullah Ghali was on a medical mission in Gaza last year. In this interview w/@annarajagopal.bsky.social, he recounts what he saw: "Sometimes kids come by themselves with very bad injuries and we have to send them to the operating room right away."
www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

‚ÄúLast year, there was no Eid. Instead of wearing new clothes, the children wore shrouds. Instead of exchanging greetings, their names were added to the lists of martyrs. The same scenes unfold today,‚Äù writes Ghada Abu Muaileq from Gaza.
www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1657...

Harvard's differential treatment of pro-Palestine students continues to draw attention. This recent IHRA adoption is just one example. In recent weeks, three faculty members have resigned in protest of student repression.  @shraddhajoshi.bsky.social reports: www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1656...

A complete ban on @unrwa.org officially went into effect last week on Jan. 30. The implementation of the ban, however, remains unclear but will cause a crisis for many Palestinians who rely on the agency's services to survive. Asma Barakat reports ‚¨áÔ∏è
www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1656...

Continue reading Amy Fallas for Palestine Square: 
www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1656...
The decision drew wide and sharp criticism from scholars who viewed the veto as suppressing an important democratic channel for membership to participate in the policies of the association.
On Thursday, Jan. 16 the AHA Council voted 11-4 with one abstention to veto the resolution on the basis that it was beyond the scope of the association's constitutionally defined purview.

...of Ukraine and Russian President Vladimir Putin's abuse of history as justification for the attack.' Opposition to the scholasticide thus deems the question of Palestine as 'political' and Palestinian lives as less valuable.‚Äù

‚ÄúHistorians who opposed the resolution also insisted that the AHA is ‚Äònot political.' We know that knowledge production is political. We also know that on Feb. 28, 2022, the AHA issued a statement ‚Äòcondemn[ing] in the strongest possible terms Russia's recent invasion...

@srseikaly.bsky.social, Associate Professor of History at UC Santa Barbara (& editor of the Journal of Palestine Studies), was the first speaker at the meeting in support of the resolution, highlighting this discrepancy of what is considered ‚Äòpolitical' for the AHA:

...such as historians Suzannah Heschel and Natalia Petrzela, appealed to political reasons for voting against the resolution...arguing it would affirm and further agitate the incoming Trump Administration's assumptions of academia as a hub for disseminating radical political agendas.

Speakers in opposition to the resolution claimed that voting in favor would politicize the AHA and endanger its future, ironically, as an advocacy organization. Although claiming to avoid politicization, some speakers...

Despite early indicators of a close vote, members were resoundingly in favor of the resolution by a vote of 428-88. Supporters attributed this victory to the months of organizing ahead of the conference as well as energized historians who mobilized awareness throughout.

The resolution was drafted and introduced by the Historians for Peace and Democracy (H-PAD), an organization that started as Historians Against War in 2003 to oppose the U.S. invasion of Iraq, now advocating for ‚Äúpeace and diplomacy internationally, and for democracy and human rights at home.‚Äù

The largest & oldest professional org of historians in the U.S. had the opportunity to make a statement on Israel's relentless destruction of educational resources in Gaza. @historians.org members voted to condemn, but their leadership issued a veto. Amy Fallas explainsüßµ‚¨áÔ∏è

Plainclothes officers in Zurich violently detained Palestinian journalist @aliabunimah.bsky.social on Jan. 25. Authorities plan to deport him this week, raising concerns among human rights groups about freedom of expression in Europe. Asma Barakat reports ‚¨áÔ∏è
www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1656...

‚ÄúI looked at the crowd that appeared from thin air, trying to take whatever their hands could reach... No one taught us how to quickly tear open boxes on the back of a moving truck as hundreds of starving people clung on‚Äù Deema Dalloul writes from Gaza.
www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1656...

@truthout.org, @prismreports.bsky.social, @palestinestudies.bsky.social, @inthesetimesmag.bsky.social, @mondoweiss.net, @therealnews.com and over 15 other organizations are members of Media Against Apartheid & Displacement, a hub site documenting Israel's occupation of Palestine. 

themaad.org

After 467 days of horror, a ceasefire deal has been reached to halt Israel's genocide in Gaza. Israel's cabinet will vote by Thursday, and the agreement is expected to take effect on Sunday. @mohamhawish.bsky.social reports for our blog, Palestine Square. palestine-studies.org/en/node/1656...

Hend writes about Dec. 15, 2024: Her brother looks for food while she studies for an exam, a strike kills dozens in the street, a drone buzzes above, ululations from a wedding nearby, heavy rain drowns tents by midnight, a dichotomy of lives in Gaza.
www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1656...

Three of my former students from Gaza have just graduated medical school amid unimaginable circumstances. I‚Äôm so beyond proud of them and so grateful to know them.

One wrote about her experience for @palestinestudies.bsky.social: www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1656...

Read the full report by @laythco.bsky.social, who mapped the response of Canada's literary community from the protests at the Giller Prize ceremony in 2023 to the #BoycottGiller campaign and counter-gala in 2024.
www.palestine-studies.org/en/node/1656...

While questions remain about the Giller Prize's continued complicity in artwashing, one thing is clear: the vast majority of writers and creators in Canada are mobilized, energized, and unwilling to sit idly while profits from genocide and arms deals funnel into Canada's literary sector.

In mid-November, critically acclaimed Madeleine Thien released a letter. Addressed to the advisory council and board of directors of the Giller Foundation, Thien requested her name, image, and work be removed entirely from all networks that link her to the foundation and its initiatives.

In an interview with the Toronto Star, author Avik Jain Chatlani argued that the systemic practice of ‚Äúartwashing the genocide in Gaza and the ethnic cleansing of the Palestinian people‚Äù continued unabated within the Giller foundation's structure, rendering the name change a hollow gesture.
In an interview with LitHub, writer and 2022 Giller Prize finalist Noor Naga, stated: ‚ÄúWe refuse to let our work distract for even a second from the filthy business of war."

Critically acclaimed author and 2021 Giller Prize winner 
Omar El Akkad, Speaking with The Walrus, stated: "If you are in support of the slaughter in Gaza, put out a statement saying so.

Mengestu speaking weeks before his resignation, warned that ‚ÄúIf you begin to lose the trust and support of the writers who make these prizes viable‚Ä¶ the legitimacy of the prize quickly begins to come under pressure.‚Äù

The fallout escalated further when two international jurors for the 2024 Giller Prize ‚Äî Indian novelist Megha Majumdar and Ethiopian-American author Dinaw Mengestu ‚Äî  resigned from their positions.

Canadian authors, including Fawn Parker, Catherine Hernandez, Avik Jain Chatlani, Canisia Lubrin, Sheung-King, Farzana Doctor, Ben Berman Ghan, Michelle Winters, and dozens of others withdrew their books from consideration for the 2024 Giller Prize.

Several past and present nominees and winners publicly declared their boycott of the prize, pledging to withhold future work from consideration until the foundation divested from its contentious sponsors.

On July 10, CanLit Responds issued a second open letter calling for the foundation to sever its partnership with sponsors implicated in Israeli war crimes, particularly Scotiabank, and galvanized a wave of resistance from the literary community.
